title: Homepage: Hero Headline & CTA
description:
Weather-related and flood damage losses are well over $50 billion annually. And cost insurance companies more than $16 billion per year.

What if... water was no longer the enemy?
What if... there is something that not only stands up to water but beats it?
What would you pay for that?

Discover how we can conquer water.

title: Homepage: Water Damages Homes
description: It can warp floors and worse -- ruin electrical systems, corrode plumbing, destroy ceilings and walls, cause mold growth, and weaken structural integrity.

title: Homepage: Water Hurts Recycling
description: Wet cardboard creates many problems. It's harder to sort and wets other recyclables, making for messy pickup and handling. Even when dry, the cardboard fibers become brittle and crumbly, making it much less valuable.

title: Homepage: Fire - Another Adversary
description: It can take just 30 seconds for a small flame to turn into a major blaze. There's a yearly average of 358,300 home-based fires, causing an estimated $15.9 billion in property damage.

title: Homepage: Water Destroys Paper
description: Paper loses strength when wet. Books suffer damage due to swelling. Mold begins to grow when objects left damp for 72 hours.

title: Homepage: Challenge - Biodegradability
description: We require products that naturally break down and are not toxic to our environment.

title: Homepage: Challenge - Repulpability
description: Materials should break down after repeat use. For example, converting paper back to pulp to be used again.

title: Homepage: Challenge - Resistance to Insects
description: Over time, we must ensure effectiveness and control over pest populations such as termites.

title: Homepage: Challenge - Strength-to-Weight Ratio
description: We need materials that are as light as paper yet as strong as steel.

title: Homepage: Challenge - Thermal Insulation
description: Cups that can easily keep hot items hot and cold items cold with no condensation or "sweating."

title: Homepage: Polymer Fibers Statement
description:
POLYMER FIBERS ARE NO LONGER THE BEST ANSWER

Using chemicals and plastics when manufacturing paper or construction materials has limitations -- the chemicals involved to treat products are toxic. And these products are not sustainable or recyclable. And natural fibers, though more desirable from a sustainability aspect, don't hold up well.

title: Homepage: 4R's Headline
description: It's time for products that meet the 4 R's: Reusable, Recyclable, Reducible, and Remarkable

title: Homepage: Reducible
description: Using less material to conserve natural resources.

title: Homepage: Recyclable
description: If unable to be put back into circulation, products can be broken down easily, cost-effectively, and efficiently recreated to be used again.

title: Homepage: Reusable
description: With nominal effort, products can be put back into circulation with minimal treatment or maintenance.

title: Homepage: Remarkable
description: It's Time for Remarkable. We need a broader class of materials that simultaneously solves many challenges, including water/insect resistance and repellence, fire suppression, unprecedented power-to-weight ratio, repulpability, biodegradability, and viable thermal insulation.

title: Homepage: Industry - Pulp/Paper Manufacturing
description:
Create cost-effective paper products made with natural fibers that are water and mildew resistant, with chemicals safe for humans and the environment, and no harmful by-products.

Create treated paper products that are completely recyclable, remain breathable, work with existing processes with little or no modifications, and can include fire protection.

title: Homepage: Industry - Construction Materials
description:
Create cost-effective building products made with natural fibers that can be made fire/water/mildew resistant, with chemicals safe for humans and the environment.

Create products that are 25% lighter than current materials yet remain strong and durable, are completely recyclable, remain breathable, and work with existing manufacturing processes.

title: Homepage: Our Mission
description: BEST is implementing innovative chemistry to make products manufactured from organic fibers more sustainable, more reusable, and more recyclable. This proprietary chemistry can make a wide range of products -- from paper production to construction materials -- water- and swell-resistant.

title: Homepage: Our Vision
description: Wherever organic fibers are used in manufacturing, BEST wants to integrate its innovative chemistry to make products better -- for the environment and for the world.

title: Homepage: Our Purpose
description: A Better, Sustainable Future Through Chemistry + Organic Fibers

title: Technology: What Is Our Technology?
description: Through a proprietary chemical process that molecularly binds with cellulose fibers, we have been able to "lock the fibers," so they are no longer susceptible to moisture.

title: Technology: What Is Promising About It?
description:
By preventing absorption, the material no longer weakens or swells when exposed to water, maintaining its structural integrity and strength.

Our process alters natural fibers to allow air to pass through, making the material breathable and further removing the threat of water damage.

Through chemical and molecular innovations, we are developing new cellulosic fiber-based products that allow for reduced consumption, while increasing reusability and recyclability -- all at a fraction of the cost of traditional products.

title: Technology: Cellulose Primer
description:
Cellulose is an organic compound and the most abundant biopolymer on Earth. It is an important structural component of green plants used in manufacturing paper and cardboard products. Around 90% of shipped products in the US are packaged in cardboard.

The properties of cellulose make it attractive as a substitute for plastics. However, the challenge with cellulose is its water content and absorption, which can contribute to degradation leading to poor mechanical properties and reduced product life.

What is needed is a way to strengthen the cellulose at the molecular level, which historically has been a complex phenomenon.

title: Technology: Traditional Cardboard vs. BEST Treatment
description: Today's cardboard technology involves recycled material and new cellulose from harvesting wood. It is pulped, filtered, blended, placed on a conveyer belt, and blasted with heat. Cardboard takes approximately 12 months to completely decompose. In landfills, it deteriorates and chemically breaks down, releasing methane -- which impacts the environment 20 times more than carbon dioxide.

title: Technology: Our Treated Cellulose Solution
description: Our solution involves treating cellulose at the molecular level. It is not a surfactant (Surface Active Agent). We developed a proprietary method that involves bonding with cellulose molecules at the chemical level. As a result, we have developed technology that can meet a range of challenges that existing products are unable to meet.

title: Product: Retail Pallets - Overview
description: With roughly 2 billion pallets circulating in the United States, global retailers want to reduce their carbon footprint through sustainable and eco-friendly operations. Since these retailers carry vast inventories and depend on complex supply chain operations, they want sustainable solutions to transport goods. One efficient, cost-effective option? Recycled cardboard pallets for retail transportation.

title: Product: Retail Pallets - Current Problems
description:
Cardboard pallets have significant liabilities:

1. Vulnerable to Moisture -- can neither sustain nor resist moisture for long periods, can't be stored outside
2. Not as Reliable as Wooden Pallets -- tendency to buckle or collapse under heavy cargo
3. Not Particularly Hygienic -- absorbent nature prevents sanitization, risking product contamination
4. Vulnerable to Legal Issues -- flimsy pallets can result in safety incidents, injuries, or fatalities

title: Product: Retail Pallets - BEST Solution
description: Through a proprietary chemical process that molecularly binds with cellulose fibers, BEST can "lock the fibers," making them resistant to moisture. The material maintains structural integrity and strength, remains breathable, and allows for reduced consumption while increasing reusability and recyclability -- at a fraction of the cost of traditional products.

title: Railroad Cargo: Problem - Moisture Vulnerability
description: Vulnerable to Moisture: Recycled cardboard used in railroad cargo packaging cannot sustain or resist moisture for extended transit periods. Rain, humidity, and condensation during rail transport weaken cardboard, causing it to lose structural integrity and fail to protect goods. This leads to damaged cargo, insurance claims, and wasted materials.

title: Railroad Cargo: Problem - Friction and Wear
description: Susceptible to Friction and Wear: The vibration and movement of rail transport subjects cardboard packaging to constant friction and mechanical stress. Over long journeys, this causes the material to weaken, tear, and disintegrate, leaving cargo exposed and unprotected before reaching its destination.

title: Railroad Cargo: Problem - Single-Use Disposal
description: Often Discarded After Single Use: Traditional cardboard packaging for railroad cargo is typically used once and then discarded. This creates enormous waste volumes, contributes to landfill burden, and represents poor economics. The inability to reuse packaging drives up per-shipment costs and increases the industry's environmental footprint.

title: Railroad Cargo: Problem - Fire Hazard
description: A Fire Hazard: Cardboard is highly flammable, posing a significant fire risk during rail transport. Sparks from rail friction, electrical issues, or external fires can ignite cardboard packaging, potentially destroying entire freight loads and creating dangerous conditions. Fire-resistant packaging materials are critical for rail safety.

title: Retail Pallets: Problem - Moisture Vulnerability
description: Vulnerable to Moisture: Cardboard pallets can neither sustain nor resist moisture for long periods. They cannot be stored outside or in humid environments. Exposure to rain, spills, or warehouse condensation causes them to weaken, warp, and potentially collapse. This makes them unreliable for retailers who need consistent supply chain performance in all conditions.

title: Retail Pallets: Problem - Reliability vs. Wood
description: Not as Reliable as Wooden Pallets: Cardboard pallets have a tendency to buckle or collapse under heavy cargo loads. Their load-bearing capacity diminishes significantly when exposed to any moisture or sustained weight over time. This unreliability compared to wooden pallets has been a major barrier to adoption, even though cardboard is more sustainable and cost-effective.

title: Retail Pallets: Problem - Hygiene Concerns
description: Not Particularly Hygienic: The absorbent nature of cardboard prevents proper sanitization, creating a risk of product contamination. In food, pharmaceutical, and retail supply chains, hygiene is critical. Untreated cardboard can harbor bacteria, mold, and other contaminants that transfer to products, making it unsuitable for industries with strict sanitation requirements.

title: Retail Pallets: Problem - Legal Liability
description: Vulnerable to Legal Issues: Flimsy or weakened pallets can result in safety incidents, injuries, or fatalities in warehouse and retail environments. Collapsed pallets can cause falling merchandise, forklift accidents, and worker injuries. This exposes companies to lawsuits, regulatory fines, workers' compensation claims, and reputational damage.

title: About: Richard S. Lacour - Bio
description: Richard S. Lacour, Co-founder & Chairman of the Board. BEST has successfully pioneered an environmentally safe process to treat biomass delivering various degrees of hydrophobicity. Mr. Lacour places high emphasis on the environment and sustainability as owner of two of the largest carbon credit projects in Brazil, preserving millions of hectares of Amazon rainforest. CPA background with Arthur Anderson LLP; founded own public accounting practice. Also a Certified Public Insurance Adjuster who directly advised the Governor of Louisiana following the BP Oil Spill.

title: About: Dr. Robert Morton - Bio
description: Dr. Robert Morton, Chief Science Officer. Over 45 years in American industry. Chief materials scientist at Phillips 66 for 30 years with 24 patents. Discovered chemistry driving regenerable materials for removing sulfur from petroleum products. Developed standard analytical methods used by the U.S. EPA worldwide. Pioneer in elemental x-ray imaging (XRF imaging), contributed to recovery of lost works of Archimedes and imaging the Archaeopteryx. Ph.D. in Chemistry from University of Missouri-Kansas City.

title: About: Fred D. Lowder - Bio
description: Fred D. Lowder, Chief Commercial Officer. Responsible for developing and leading BEST's commercial and market development. Industrial chemist with significant experience in technical groups and strategic sales management. 37-year career in petroleum industry, leading expert in Pentane, Hexane, and Heptane solvents. Instrumental in converting PIMA foam blowing from freon to pentane. At Phillips 66, led Solvents team to increase net profit from $38MM/yr to $64MM/yr. B.S. in Math and Chemistry Education from West Texas State University.

title: About: Mark A. Parrish - Bio
description: Mark A. Parrish, Managing Director and CEO. Proven leader in company transformation and shareholder value with deep knowledge of industrials and technology. Senior leadership experience in sustainability, operational excellence, corporate strategy, M&A, and emerging technologies. Led world-class manufacturers including Ply Gem Windows, Interface Inc., and Deceuninck North America. Two M.S. degrees from MIT (Mechanical Engineering and Operations Management). B.S. from West Point. Former U.S. Army AH-64 Apache pilot; received Bronze Star and Air Medal for Valor.

title: About: Russell Moffett - Bio
description: Russell Moffett, Sales Manager. 34 years of experience in petroleum and chemical industries. Most recently Mid-Continent Region Sales Manager for Phillips 66 Specialty Solvents (17+ years). Career began with Schlumberger as Field Engineer, progressing through various roles in South Louisiana and Texas. Experience in refined products, light hydrocarbons, and calcined petroleum coke. Serves on Mississippi State University Petroleum Engineering Advisory Board. B.S. in Petroleum Engineering from Mississippi State University.

title: About: Sam McCalmont - Bio
description: Sam McCalmont. 37 years of experience in specialty chemical business and specialty hydrocarbons. Career at Callery Chemical (business development, product development, sales management), then Phillips Petroleum/Phillips 66 Specialty Solvents (Northeast Territory Manager including Canada, Europe, and Middle East). B.S. in Chemistry from Marshall University.
